10.title: Building Bridges: Tools for Social Cohesion
10.content: This course explores the roots of social fragmentation and equips students with tools and strategies to foster social cohesion and constructive communication within groups. By blending theory and practice, students will learn how to analyze challenges in public and personal spheres, design dialogue processes, and build teams structured to organize community conversations. The course introduces and builds civic muscles such as deep listening, facilitation, and coaching, as well as broader change-making techniques like diagnosing challenges, strategizing, and taking action. Through lectures, skills-based labs, and a conversation project, students will practice designing and leading meaningful conversations, leveraging AI-assisted sensemaking, and creating impactful outputs to share with their communities. This hands-on course prepares students to build civic muscles for engaging with the complexities of public life and driving positive social change. Schedule .

11.title: Course Information
11.content: Instructors: . | Deb Roy (dkroy@media.mit.edu) | Maggie Hughes (mhughes4@media.mit.edu) | Dimitra Dimitrakopoulou (dimitrad@media.mit.edu) | Danny Kessler (kessler1@media.mit.edu) | . Meeting Time and Location: Tuesdays . | 10:30 AM - 12:00 PM ET | E15-359 | . Thursdays . | 10:30 PM - 12:00 PM ET | E15-341 | . Credit Hours: 3-0-9 .

12.title: Intended Learning Goals
12.content: Students should leave this course with: . | A baseline understanding of why social fragmentation occurs | Knowledge of how to foster social cohesion within a group | Skills to design a small-scale team for social cohesion | An initial set of tools and methods for building civic muscles for constructive communication | .

13.title: Course Structure
13.content: The course combines: . | Lectures covering key concepts based on weekly readings | Discussion-based learning requiring pre-reading preparation | Practical labs for building civic muscles | Hands-on project work | .

14.title: Grading Criteria
14.content: | Component | Weight | . | Classroom participation | 35% | . | Weekly assignments | 15% | . | Midterm Project proposal | 15% | . | Final project | 35% | .

15.title: Course Project
15.content: Scope and Objectives . The goal of this course project is to develop and run a conversation-based initiative within a defined community, fostering meaningful engagement and dialogue. The project may focus on: . | A pre-existing community where you are already an active participant (e.g., the Media Lab community or some other community you are part of at MIT) | A new community where you seek to establish yourself as a member (e.g., a group of freshmen in Massie Hall striving for deeper engagement at MIT) | . The scope emphasizes accessibility, relevance, and the creation of a brave space for participants to engage openly and honestly.

21.title: Cortico Platform
21.content: Coming Soon . A platform for facilitating and recording meaningful conversations across communities.

22.title: AI Sensemaking
22.content: Coming Soon . Tools and techniques for using AI to analyze and derive insights from conversation data.

23.title: Coalesce
23.content: Coming Soon . A collaborative platform for synthesizing insights from multiple conversations and sources.

24.title: Pol.is
24.content: Coming Soon . An AI-powered platform for gathering and visualizing public opinion at scale.

25.title: Conversation Mapping Tool
25.content: Beta . A prototype tool for mapping and analyzing conversation patterns and themes. Work with the prototyping team to access and provide feedback.

26.title: Facilimate
26.content: Coming Soon . A tool to assist in planning and facilitating effective group discussions and dialogues.

27.title: Relationship Mapping
27.content: Coming Soon . Tools and templates for mapping organizational relationships and power structures.

28.title: Visualization Tools
28.content: Coming Soon . Tools for creating visual representations of data and insights. Sensemap . A tool for creating visual representations of complex information and relationships. Visualization Notebook . Templates and guidelines for creating effective data visualizations.

29.title: Basic Documentation
29.content: Available Now . At minimum, you should use tools to: . | Take detailed notes | Document key insights and patterns | Track relationships and connections | Maintain a shared team documentation space | . Recommended Tools . | Google Docs/Drive for collaborative note-taking | Miro/Mural for visual documentation | Voice recording apps (with participant consent) | Photography/video (with participant consent) | .

32.title: Week 1: Why Build Bridges?
32.content: Tues, Feb 4 | Lecture: Explore the details of the course, dive deeper into MIT Center for Constructive Communication’s key projects, and discuss the macro factors—economic, social, technological—that contribute to social fragmentation. | No readings this week | . Thurs, Feb 6 | Lab: Public Narrative . | Start Public Narrative | . | Iterate on your story of self draft | .

33.title: Week 2: Fractured Communities: Understanding Societal Challenges
33.content: Tues, Feb 11 | Lecture: Examine the roots of societal issues, such as weakened institutions, declining trust in media, and toxic social media. Discuss the role of civic associations and the importance of local politics in fostering democracy. | Roy, D. (2023, October 17). The Internet could be so good. Really. The Atlantic [link] | Bohm, D. (1996). On dialogue. New York: Routledge, pp. 1-5 | Herzig, M. and Chasin, L. (2006). Fostering dialogue across divides | Bowling Alone Chapter 1: Thinking about Social Change in America | .
